title: 107_hr2971
content: SECTION 1. GRANTING OF COPYRIGHT. Copyright is granted to Inna Hecker Grade and her successors in the works of Chaim Grade for 50 years from June 26, 1982. The copyright owner has all rights and remedies provided by law, with no liability for lawful uses made before the enactment of this Act. SEC. 2. WORK SUBJECT TO COPYRIGHT. Chaim Grade's works covered in section 1 include various titles such as "Yo," "Musarnikes," "Dojrois," "Oyf di Hurves," "Pleitim," "Farvoksene Vegn," "Der Mames Tzavoe," "Shayn fun Farloshene Shtern," "Mayn Krig Mit Hersh Rassayner," "Yerushalaim shel Maylah, Yerushalaim shel Matah," "Hurbin," and "Vilna" with different parts like "Di Shank." Chaim Grade's works in section 1 include titles like "Yerushalaim shel Maylah, Yerushalaim shel Matah," "Hurbin," and "Vilna" with parts like "Di Shank" and "Der Ger-Tzadik." Other works mentioned are "Talmidei-Hahomin in der Lite," "Oyf Mayn Veg Tzu Dir," and "Dos Alte Hoyz" with alternate titles like "Zin un Tahter" and "Der Beth-Horav." Chaim Grade's works include titles like "Talmidei-Hahomin in der Lite," "Oyf Mayn Veg Tzu Dir," and "Dos Alte Hoyz" with alternate titles like "Zin un Tahter" and "Der Beth-Horav." Other works mentioned are "Fun Unter der Erd," "Yury Goresha," "Alte Boherim," and "In Gerangl mitn Malah." Chaim Grade's works include various titles such as "Chaim Nachman Bialik," "H. Leivik, The Poet of Suffering and Fate," "Itzik Manger, the Poet of Beauty and Play," "Three Yiddish Classics," and "Anski, the Champion of Enlightenment." Itzik Manger, the Poet of Beauty and Play, is discussed along with other Yiddish classics such as Mendele, I.L. Peretz, and Sholem-Alaychem. Anski is also mentioned as the Champion of Enlightenment, the Revolutionary, and the Penitent. Additionally, there is a discussion on the problems faced by Yiddish writers and in Yiddish literature, as well as personal encounters with Soviet Yiddish writers. Three dramatic poems, including "The Golden Key," "The Golem," and "The Dybbuk," are also highlighted. Itzik Manger, Mendele, I.L. Peretz, and Sholem-Alaychem are discussed in relation to Yiddish literature. Various topics such as personal encounters with Soviet Yiddish writers, three dramatic poems, and the Sabbath in Yiddish literature are also covered. In the curr_chunk, various topics related to Yiddish literature are discussed, including the Sabbath, Lithuanian Yeshivas, Rabbi Israel Baal Shem Tov, Rabbi Israel Salanter, and the Talmudic Scholar. The curr_chunk discusses various topics in Yiddish literature, such as Talmudic scholars, memorial services, Jewish philosophy, struggles for Jewish life, Yiddish writers in Soviet Russia, and Rabbi Jehudah Ibn Samuel Dr. Kaufman. The curr_chunk covers a range of topics in Yiddish literature, including lectures and essays on Saffed, Mount Miron, Israel, Vilna, and the Histadruth organization. The curr_chunk includes lectures and essays on various topics in Yiddish literature, such as Saffed, Mount Miron, Israel, Vilna, the Histadruth organization, the New Hebrew Literature in Israel, and the survivors of the German concentration camps. The curr_chunk lists various lectures and essays on Yiddish literature topics including American Yiddish poets, survivors of German concentration camps, the soil and legend of Israel, and controversies among rabbis in Vilna. The curr_chunk includes works by Chaim Grade and American Yiddish poets Morris Rosenfeld, Avrohom Reisen, Walt-Lessin, and Mani Leib.
